title: Latin (1250) Morgan Crusader Bible (Manuscript)
description:
Latin (1250) Morgan Crusader Bible (Manuscript)

The Morgan Crusader Bible, also known as the Maciejowski Bible, the Morgan Bible, and the Shah 'Abbas Bible, is an illustrious medieval manuscript of exceptional historical and artistic significance. Commissioned around 1250 by King Louis IX of France, who was later canonized as Saint Louis, this masterpiece represents a remarkable confluence of spirituality, art, and politics during the Middle Ages. Crafted by leading Parisian artists of the time, the Bible is a vivid depiction of biblical narratives, primarily focusing on the Old Testament.

Standing over a foot tall, the Morgan Crusader Bible is distinguished by its visual storytelling, containing more than 380 scenes that span from the Creation to the reign of King David. This pictorial bible was initially created without any textual explanations, offering a purely visual interpretation of biblical events. Its images are characterized by their detail, vibrancy, and the dynamic portrayal of characters and scenes, making it an invaluable resource for understanding medieval art and biblical interpretation.
